title: App Features
text:
The app has multiple features, including:

View live wait times
Find alternative services, such as GP and pharmacies
Access information on health conditions and treatments
Option to call 111 (for advice) or 999 (emergencies only)


View live wait times:
This is the primary function of NHSquicker. Two option to view this, either on the list view or map view:

 



Alternative Services:
The app also provides information for alternative services such as GP and pharmacies:







Health Conditions and Treatments:
The app provides access to information on health conditions and treatments from https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/.


Call 111 or 999

title: Evidence & Analytics
text:
Since launching in 2017, NHSquicker has expanded to cover 37 urgent care facilities serving 1.9 million people across Devon, Cornwall and Somerset. Early data shows a positive shift in patient behavior, with reductions in A&E attendance and increased use of MIUs and UTCs. The app also won the Lyn Thomas Impact Medal for demonstrating strong real-world impact and was featured as a REF2021 Impact Case Study.



Unique users graph (17/01/20 - 18/11/25)


The Unique Users graph shows the number of individual user who engaged with the app on a given day. From when we started collecting data (17th Jan 2020) to the present, the number of users per day has increased, and is expected to continue increasing.



Wait time difference split graph (17/01/20 - 19/11/25)


This graph shows summarises user decision-making based on differences in wait times between the closest unit to the user and the unit that the user viewed more options for when viewing wait times on the NHSquicker app. Users most often clicked on units that had shorter wait times than the unit that was closest to them, indicating users are interested in shorter wait times, even if it means travelling further. This highlights the importance of the app for providing real-time wait time information for guiding decisions.





Looking at cases where the nearest unit at the time was an emergency department, the graph shows that from the start of data collection to the present, users selected a unit with a shorter wait 87.2% of the time. The emphasises the usefulness of NHSquicker, and shows its importance in decision making.

title: Research & Publications
text:
Links to Research Papers:

  
  
  



Finalist at the HSJ
NHSquicker has featured on BBC News.

What is NHSquicker

NHSquicker is a free app providing live wait times for NHS services in Devon, Cornwall and Somerset. It was created to help people make smarter healthcare choices and reduce unnecessary pressure on the NHS.

NHSquicker is a free app which provides live wait time information for NHS services in Devon, Cornwall and Somerset. It was developed to help people make informed decisions about where to go for urgent, non-life-threatening care. By showing live waiting times, travel times, and service availability across emergency departments, minor injury units (MIUs) and urgent treatment centres (UTCs), the app guides users to the most appropriate service. This helps reduce unnecessary pressure on A&E departments, improving overally patient experience and flow.

NHSquicker is a free app which provides live wait time information for NHS services in Devon, Cornwall and Somerset. It was developed to help people make informed decisions about where to go for urgent, non-life-threatening care. By showing live waiting times, travel times, and service availability across emergency departments, minor injury units (MIUs) and urgent treatment centres (UTCs), the app guides users to the most appropriate service. This helps reduce unnecessary pressure on A&E departments, improving overally patient experience and flow.

Why the app was developed
A&E services across England have faced increasing pressure, with many departments struggling to meet the national 4 hour standard. Research from the University of Exeter and NHS partners found that while MIUs and UTCs often met waiting time targets, A&E departments were underperforming due to high demand. NHSquicker was developed to address this challenge by helping patients choose suitable alternatives with shorter waits, reducing overcrowding and supporting the urgent-care network.

Who the App is For
NHSquicker is designed for members of the public with urgent but not life-threatening health concerns, helping them quickly locate nearby care options. It also benefits NHS organisations by supporting better distribution of patient demand across regional urgent-care services.

Who Developed It

The app is a collaboration between the University of Exeter, NHS organisations across Devon, Cornwall and Somerset, and system integration partners. The platform has evolved through joint work with NHS analysts, clinicians, operational researchers, and digital transformation teams. The project forms part of the Health and Care IMPACT Network, supporting data-driven improvements in urgent and emergency care.

The Problem It Solves
High attendance at A&E for non-emergency conditions leads to long waiting times, overcrowding, and poorer experiences for patients. Many patients could be safely treated at MIUs or UTCs but lack awareness of nearby alternatives. NHSquicker addresses this by providing real-time, practical information - helping people go to the right place, at the right time, and reducing avoidable A&E attendances.
